comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: They would need SCUBA gear now - it is under Warragamba Dam. 1937 interactive map showing extensive settlements swamped by the lake - www.nla.gov.au/apps/cdview?pi=nla.map-vn4180400-sd&rg...

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Thanks for the info; we've changed the date above to pre-1937.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw] It is only the map which is dated 1937;  I don't know when the area was flooded; probably about 1960.  But late 1930s seems about right for many of these photos for railway carriage decoration.

comment.author: 7272097@N08
comment._content: Great photo and love the map. I own a more recent version of the map. Also, I've uploaded a couple of my father's photos of Burragorang Valley in the 1950s to Flickr.

comment.author: 51487922@N05
comment._content:
The Lake Macquarie & District Historical Society hold an original of this photograph, the caption reads as follows;

This delightful view shows a pretty crossing-place on Cox's River, and further illustrates the beauty to be found within Burragorang Valley. The Valley may be reached by train to Campbelltown, 32 miles from Sydney, thence by service cars. Sporting pleasures available include horse-riding, hiking, swimming, tennis and golf.

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/51487922@N05] Thanks for the extra info; it sounds like a wonderful place to visit!
